doc.repnme: Transcript of oral history interview with William Gilmartin held on November 14, 1985
doc.abstracts: In November 1985, William Gilmartin was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by Robert W. Oliver. During his tenure at the Bank from 1946 to 1978, Mr. Gilmartin worked in the following areas: in the economics department as an economist (1946-1954); in the Asia and Middle East department as an assistant economic advisor (1954-1956); in Thailand as a resident representative (1956-1957) and as deputy chief and chief economist (1957-1958); in the department of operations, as economic advisor to the Far East (1958-1965); in the Asia department as economic advisor (1966-1967); in India as a resident representative (1967-1970) and as resident representative (1972-1976); in the East Asia and Pacific (EAP) region as chief economist (1970-1972); and in the South Asia region as chief economist (1975-1976) and as senior advisor (1976-1978). He was responsible for the operations concerned with assessments of the creditworthiness of Japan. His transcript concerns the relationship of the World Bank with India and its industrialization program, as wells as Thailand and its limitations on their budget deficit and foreign borrowing.
